content:
I'm trying to get my head around ends and coends. I like to learn from examples, which are weirdly hard to find for this topic, but I did find one in CWM (on p. 226):

image.png

This makes a vague sort of qualitative sense to me. I don't know anything about modules, but I guess I can just replace "ring" with "field" and "module" with "vector space" and everything will be the same (except I guess the op^\mathrm{op}op won't matter any more, because a field in this context is a commutative monoid with an extra operation defined on it, and commutative monoids are their own opposites).

However, I'm a bit confused. It makes sense to me that a module (or a vector space) is a functor from RRR to Ab\mathbf{Ab}Ab in the sense described. But surely the tensor product of two vector spaces ought to be another vector space, which means I'd expect it also to be a functor from RRR to Ab\mathbf{Ab}Ab. The coend "integrates out" the dependence on RRR, so it doesn't give a functor from RRR to Ab\mathbf{Ab}Ab but only an Abelian group. This makes it hard for me to see how the object MMM can be the tensor product of AAA and BBB.

Can anyone figure out what my confusion is and help me resolve it?

Nathaniel Virgo said:

However, I'm a bit confused. It makes sense to me that a module (or a vector space) is a functor from RRR to Ab\mathbf{Ab}Ab in the sense described. But surely the tensor product of two vector spaces ought to be another vector space, which means I'd expect it also to be a functor from RRR to Ab\mathbf{Ab}Ab.

This is almost true. The tensor product of two RRR-modules is not, in general, an RRR-module! This is because the tensor kills the right module structure of the first module and the left module structure of the second module, because you want bilinearity.
In symbols: if AAA is a (R,S)(R, S)(R,S)-bimodule (i.e., a left RRR-module and a right SSS-module) and BBB is a (S,T)(S, T)(S,T)-bimodule, then you can form their SSS-tensor product A⊗SBA \otimes_S BA⊗S​B which has the structure of a (R,T)(R, T)(R,T)-bimodule (notice the SSS-module structure was killed).

If RRR is commutative though, every left RRR-module is also a right RRR-module (because R=RopR = R^{op}R=Rop), and thus carries the structure of a (R,R)(R,R)(R,R)-bimodule. This means that the category of RRR-modules is monoidal with respect to ⊗R\otimes_R⊗R​.

Back to the true question: why is R↦A⊗ZBR \mapsto A \otimes_{\Bbb Z} BR↦A⊗Z​B (also this notation is extremely confusing: the RRR I just wrote is the single, dummy object of the one-object category RRR) a functor Rop×R→AbR^{op} \times R \to AbRop×R→Ab? Well, because A⊗ZBA \otimes_{\Bbb Z} BA⊗Z​B is an (R,R)(R,R)(R,R)-bimodule! :laughing:
In practical terms, there's an action of RRR both on the left and the right.

If you look at the cowedge diagram, you see what it means: if you choose an element r∈Rr \in Rr∈R, you can use it to multiply an element a⊗b∈A⊗ZBa \otimes b \in A \otimes_{\Bbb Z} Ba⊗b∈A⊗Z​B on the left or on the right

Matteo Capucci said:

If you look at the cowedge diagram, you see what it means: if you choose an element r∈Rr \in Rr∈R, you can use it to multiply an element a⊗b∈A⊗ZBa \otimes b \in A \otimes_{\Bbb Z} Ba⊗b∈A⊗Z​B on the left or on the right

Yes, this is also the intuition behind opitcs as coends btw. You are taking pairs of morphisms (f,g)(f,g)(f,g). Now you want to depict these as a comb, so you want to interpret fff as ``connected'' with ggg. But what does this mean in practice? It means, string diagrammatically, that if f,gf,gf,g are connected by a wire you can put another morphism on that wire and you can slide it freely towards fff or towards ggg. This means that you want to identify pairs (f;h,g)(f ; h, g)(f;h,g) and (f,h′;g)(f, h' ;g)(f,h′;g) for whatever h,h′h, h'h,h′ for which these compositions make sense and typecheck, and this is precisely what the coend does for you
(I don't know if this explanation makes things more clear or more confused, if it's the former I'm sorry D: )

Now you want this two actions to be the same, i.e. you want to homogeneize A⊗ZBA \otimes_{\Bbb Z} BA⊗Z​B with respect to the actions of RRR. This means imposing r⋅(a⊗b)=(a⊗b)⋅rr \cdot (a \otimes b) = (a \otimes b) \cdot rr⋅(a⊗b)=(a⊗b)⋅r (+ linearity), which is what gives you the RRR-tensor of AAA and BBB.
That's what the coend says. Maybe a more explicit notation would have been:
∫r∈Rr⋅(A⊗ZB)⋅r\int^{r \in R} r \cdot (A \otimes_{\Bbb Z} B) \cdot r∫r∈Rr⋅(A⊗Z​B)⋅r

Fabrizio Genovese said:

Matteo Capucci said:

If you look at the cowedge diagram, you see what it means: if you choose an element r∈Rr \in Rr∈R, you can use it to multiply an element a⊗b∈A⊗ZBa \otimes b \in A \otimes_{\Bbb Z} Ba⊗b∈A⊗Z​B on the left or on the right

Yes, this is also the intuition behind opitcs as coends btw. You are taking pairs of morphisms (f,g)(f,g)(f,g). Now you want to depict these as a comb, so you want to interpret fff as ``connected'' with ggg. But what does this mean in practice? It means, string diagrammatically, that if f,gf,gf,g are connected by a wire you can put another morphism on that wire and you can slide it freely towards fff or towards ggg. This means that you want to identify pairs (f;h,g)(f ; h, g)(f;h,g) and (f,h′;g)(f, h' ;g)(f,h′;g) for whatever h,h′h, h'h,h′ for which these compositions make sense and typecheck, and this is precisely what the coend does for you

Indeed, the structure involved is the same: a left RRR-module is just an object with a monoidal action from RRR!

Fabrizio Genovese said:

Yes, this is also the intuition behind opitcs as coends btw. You are taking pairs of morphisms (f,g)(f,g)(f,g). Now you want to depict these as a comb, so you want to interpret fff as ``connected'' with ggg. But what does this mean in practice? It means, string diagrammatically, that if f,gf,gf,g are connected by a wire you can put another morphism on that wire and you can slide it freely towards fff or towards ggg. This means that you want to identify pairs (f;h,g)(f ; h, g)(f;h,g) and (f,h′;g)(f, h' ;g)(f,h′;g) for whatever h,h′h, h'h,h′ for which these compositions make sense and typecheck, and this is precisely what the coend does for you

This is exactly what I'm really trying to understand - I sort of get this, but I'm trying to really get a hold of the formal details. (Just on the off chance: do you know of anywhere where coends are introduced with this kind of application in mind?)

@Matteo Capucci thank you so much for this explanation, it's really helpful.

So to summarise, I should think of vector spaces not as RRR-modules but as (R,R)(R,R)(R,R)-bimodules. Then the coend is doing this sort of thing, to leave me with another (R,R)(R,R)(R,R)-bimodule in the end. This makes sense to me.

image.png

(Don't ask me to say formally what this diagram is yet though.)
Yes, in a sense. The point is, when R is commutative every module is a bimodule. Just keep in mind this!

In the coend definition of profunctor optics, you have something more close to (R, S)-bimodules, that is, in general the left action is not the same as the right action, and might even come from a different ring
Not every (R,R)(R, R)(R,R)-bimodule is an RRR-module in the commutative sense though, just the ones for which the left and right actions agree, i.e., rm=mrrm = mrrm=mr
This property is preserved by this tensor product of bimodules operation.

Nathaniel Virgo said:

Fabrizio Genovese said:

Yes, this is also the intuition behind opitcs as coends btw. You are taking pairs of morphisms (f,g)(f,g)(f,g). Now you want to depict these as a comb, so you want to interpret fff as ``connected'' with ggg. But what does this mean in practice? It means, string diagrammatically, that if f,gf,gf,g are connected by a wire you can put another morphism on that wire and you can slide it freely towards fff or towards ggg. This means that you want to identify pairs (f;h,g)(f ; h, g)(f;h,g) and (f,h′;g)(f, h' ;g)(f,h′;g) for whatever h,h′h, h'h,h′ for which these compositions make sense and typecheck, and this is precisely what the coend does for you

This is exactly what I'm really trying to understand - I sort of get this, but I'm trying to really get a hold of the formal details. (Just on the off chance: do you know of anywhere where coends are introduced with this kind of application in mind?)

"Profunctor optics a categorical update" has this coend flavor imho
Indeed, it does! ∫\int∫

Anyway, see it like this: Think graphically. An optic is a comb, ok? Now you want a way to "formalize" this comb. You start noticing that if you cut the comb in half, you get two morphisms. So you may think "neat, I'll formalize the comb as a pair of morphisms". And then you have the problem I highlighted above: If you have a box living on one of the wires you split, on which side of the pair do you put it?
The coend formalization says "it doesn't matter, because we identify the pairs that can be transformed one into the other by sliding such a box."

This is probably the handwaviewst explanation of what's going on, but also the one that makes intuitively more sense in my opinion. Anyway @fosco is here and he's one of the authors of said paper, so... :smile:
The oldest paper where coend optics is written down is probably Riley's "categories of optics", but it was apparently functional programming folklore for a long time before that
I could say something on optics, but I'd rather comment on the original question posed by OP; I'll do it as soon as possible!

Nathaniel Virgo said:

Matteo Capucci thank you so much for this explanation, it's really helpful.

So to summarise, I should think of vector spaces not as RRR-modules but as (R,R)(R,R)(R,R)-bimodules. Then the coend is doing this sort of thing, to leave me with another (R,R)(R,R)(R,R)-bimodule in the end. This makes sense to me.

Digressing somewhat: a good physicist named Stephen Adler wrote a book Quaternionic Quantum Mechanics and Quantum Fields, where he tried to do quantum physics using "quaternionic Hilbert spaces", which are left modules over the quaternions. He got into a big mess when he tried to tensor these, as you must when combining quantum systems. He should have used bimodules!

You can do quantum mechanics using modules over the division algebras R\mathbb{R}R, C\mathbb{C}C or H\mathbb{H}H, but since the quaternions H\mathbb{H}H are noncommutative, if you want to tensor these modules you should probably use bimodules, and then you might as well think about things like (C,H)(\mathbb{C}, \mathbb{H})(C,H)-bimodules where one division algebra acts on the left and the other acts on the right. I haven't gotten around to studying this very much yet, despite being a bit obsessed with division algebras in quantum mechanics.
Does that mean that when you combine quantum systems in this setting, the order matters?

Thinking more on the points about modules and vector spaces: does this mean there's a general theory that can be developed about ends and coends in the case where the source category is a commutative monoid? It seems like the story Matteo Capucci told only really depends on that.

So can we say that if TTT is a commutative monoid (seen as a single-object category) and C\mathscr{C}C is a monoidal category, then can we generalise "every vector space is really a bimodule" to "any functor F ⁣:T→CF\colon T\to \mathscr{C}F:T→C is really a functor F ⁣:Top×T→CF\colon T^\text{op}\times T \to \mathscr{C}F:Top×T→C"? Then I guess we can then define a tensor product of such functors (if it exists) by a coend, which I guess would be written

(F⊗TG)(s,u)=∫t∈TF(s,t)⊗G(t,u).(F\otimes_T G)(s,u) = \int^{t\in T} F(s,t)\otimes G(t,u).(F⊗T​G)(s,u)=∫t∈TF(s,t)⊗G(t,u).

If that does work, what's the sense in which a functor T→CT\to \mathscr{C}T→C is "really" a functor Top×T→CT^\text{op}\times T\to \mathscr{C}Top×T→C? (How do we formally construct one from the other?) And does this coend construction reduce to something simpler in this case? Sorry if this is a silly question.

Nathaniel Virgo said:

(F⊗TG)(s,u)=∫t∈TF(s,t)⊗G(t,u).(F\otimes_T G)(s,u) = \int^{t\in T} F(s,t)\otimes G(t,u).(F⊗T​G)(s,u)=∫t∈TF(s,t)⊗G(t,u).

I believe this should be

(F⊗TG)(∙)=∫∙∈TF(∙)⊗G(∙).(F\otimes_T G)(\bullet) = \int^{\bullet \in T} F(\bullet)\otimes G(\bullet).(F⊗T​G)(∙)=∫∙∈TF(∙)⊗G(∙).

Matteo Capucci said:

∫r∈Rr⋅(A⊗ZB)⋅r\int^{r \in R} r \cdot (A \otimes_{\Bbb Z} B) \cdot r∫r∈Rr⋅(A⊗Z​B)⋅r

I now realized this is very bad notation, and quite wrong, since rrr is a morphism

Nathaniel Virgo said:

So can we say that if TTT is a commutative monoid (seen as a single-object category) and C\mathscr{C}C is a monoidal category, then can we generalise "every vector space is really a bimodule" to "any functor F ⁣:T→CF\colon T\to \mathscr{C}F:T→C is really a functor F ⁣:Top×T→CF\colon T^\text{op}\times T \to \mathscr{C}F:Top×T→C"?

I believe the answer to be yes, let's check. For clarity, let me call TTT the monoid and BT\mathbf BTBT its delooping, i.e. the one-object (the object is ∙\bullet∙) category whose only hom-set is TTT.
A functor F:BT→CF: \mathbf B T \to \mathscr CF:BT→C is the choice of an object XXX of C\mathscr CC and an homomorphism of monoids T→End(X)T \to \mathrm{End}(X)T→End(X).
We can denote the action of t∈Tt \in Tt∈T on XXX as t⋅−t \cdot -t⋅−, so we say FFF is a left action.
Now, since TTT is commutative, BT=BTop\mathbf B T = \mathbf B T^{op}BT=BTop, we see that FFF is also a right action, that is, a functor BTop→C\mathbf B T^{op} \to \mathscr CBTop→C picking again XXX as the object but acting now on XXX on the right, i.e. we write −⋅t- \cdot t−⋅t for the endomorphism induced by t∈Tt \in Tt∈T.
Suppose now that C\mathscr CC is monoidal. Then given G,T:BT→CG, T : \mathbf B T \to \mathscr CG,T:BT→C, we can tensor it by putting together their target object using C\mathscr CC's monoidal product, and then having one acting on the left and one on the right.
More precisely, we get an action of Top×T=T×TT^{op} \times T = T \times TTop×T=T×T embodied by a functor G⊗TF:BT2→CG \otimes_T F : \mathbf B T^2 \to \mathscr CG⊗T​F:BT2→C. Notice that BT2=BTop×BT=BT×BT\mathbf B T^2 = \mathbf B T^{op} \times \mathbf B T = \mathbf B T \times \mathbf B TBT2=BTop×BT=BT×BT. The functor acts on objects by sending ∙\bullet∙ to G(∙)⊗F(∙)G(\bullet) \otimes F(\bullet)G(∙)⊗F(∙), and on morphisms by sending (s,t)(s,t)(s,t) to s⋅−⊗−⋅ts \cdot - \otimes - \cdot ts⋅−⊗−⋅t.
A bit of terminology: X:CX : \mathscr CX:C with an action of TTT is called a left TTT-module in C\mathscr CC. In other words, left TTT-modules in C\mathscr CC are functors BT→C\mathbf BT \to \mathscr CBT→C. Unsurprisingly, they form a category, that we could denote by T−CModT-\mathscr C\mathrm{Mod}T−CMod. Morphisms are natural transformations. In the same vein, we get a category CMod−T\mathscr C\mathrm{Mod}-TCMod−T of right TTT-modules in C\mathscr CC. A TTT-bimodule in C\mathscr CC is just a left and right TTT-module, i.e. an object of C\mathscr CC equipped with a left and right action of TTT, i.e. a functor BTop×BT→C\mathbf B T^{op} \times \mathbf B T \to \mathscr CBTop×BT→C.
Notice that CMod−Top=T−CMod\mathscr C\mathrm{Mod}-T^{op} = T-\mathscr C\mathrm{Mod}CMod−Top=T−CMod, that is, left TTT-modules are the same thing as right TopT^{op}Top-modules. Therefore, when TTT is commutative, right and left modules are the same thing!

The last step is probably to show that you need the coend to define a functorial monoidal product in the category of bimodules, since their product otherwise ignores the actions 'in the middle', which then you need to quotient out.
